BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and very particularly the wind slabs that are forming above approximately 2200 m represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Wednesday above approximately 1800 m, in particular along the border with France.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, soft wind slabs will form above the tree line.
The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep north, east and south facing slopes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially above approximately 2300 m.
In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible. In their paths avalanches can entrain the wet snow. In the typical avalanche paths these can reach low altitudes.
More wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses below approximately 2200 m.
Meticulous route selection is recommended.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual, in particular above approximately 2200 m.
25 to 50 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And a rapid settlement of the snowpack below about 2500 m
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will decrease quickly.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are prone to triggering in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised in particular above approximately 2200 m, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Avalanches can be released easily and reach medium size. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.

There is a danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides. This applies on steep slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. The wind will be moderate over a wide area. As a consequence of new snow and wind from variable directions, further wind slabs will form. More recent wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 50 cm of snow will fall on Wednesday above approximately 1800 m.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, soft wind slabs will form above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
From starting zones at higher altitudes more small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible. In their paths avalanches can entrain the wet snow.
More wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And a rapid settlement of the snowpack below about 2500 m
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will decrease quickly.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are not ruled out, in particular in case of releases originating from steep starting zones above approximately 2500 m. In the last few days sometimes easily released wind slabs formed at elevated altitudes. Single backcountry tourers can release avalanches, including medium-sized ones. In some places avalanches can also penetrate down to the ground and reach large size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
The current avalanche situation calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m. As a consequence of sharply falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate during the next few days. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of falling temperatures, the avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger, especially at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed at elevated altitudes. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to east to south facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Gradual decrease in danger of moist avalanches as the temperature drops, in the regions exposed to rain in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet gave rise on Monday to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of sharply falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate during the next few days. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are bonding well with the old snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below approximately 2100 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 15 cm of snow will fall on Wednesday above approximately 1800 m.
As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs formed at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on extremely steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
More wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since Monday above approximately 2500 m.
In all altitude zones only a little snow is now lying. The snowpack is largely stable. The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. And a rapid settlement of the snowpack below about 2500 m
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will decrease quickly.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on near-ridge shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1000 m snow will fall on Wednesday in particular in the Dolomites. In some regions 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2000 m. The new snow will be deposited on a crust in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. The large surface-area wind slabs of the last few days have bonded quite well with the old snowpack. They must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs can be released by large loads in particular. At the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall on Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. As the snowfall becomes more intense the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: On Thursday the wind will be moderate to strong in some localities over a wide area. In the regions where the wind is stronger danger level 3 (considerable) may be reached.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering above approximately 2200 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

On steep slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from variable directions, wind slabs will form in all aspects. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released easily even by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate wind from variable directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form on Wednesday in all aspects. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will bring about a slight settling of the snow drift accumulations in the late morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering above approximately 2200 m. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places even by individual winter sport participants especially at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from variable directions, wind slabs will form in all aspects. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. The weather conditions will foster a slow settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are prone to triggering above approximately 2200 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

There is a danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from variable directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form in all aspects. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will cause a slow settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain.
In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls. As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will decrease.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is moist. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m. As a consequence of sharply falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate during the next few days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a substantial strengthening of the snowpack in particular below approximately 2700 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
Gliding avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some regions 10 to 20 cm of snow, but less in some localities, will fall. The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
Gliding avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some regions 10 to 20 cm of snow, but less in some localities, will fall. The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be moist below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow is lying on top of a weakly bonded old snowpack in all aspects below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack is moist; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1200 m snow will fall on Wednesday in some localities. In some regions 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. In these regions danger level 1 (low) will be reached.

The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will soften quickly. Isolated small avalanches are possible in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains generally subject to considerable local variations. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls mostly small wind slabs formed. As a consequence of rising temperatures the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling here.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
